2c3cc9eb.message: 'cp949' codec can't encode character '\u2705' in position 0
contexts: Python print() or file write operations on Windows
2c3cc9eb.solution: Replace all emoji with ASCII alternatives. Use [OK], [FAIL], [WARN] instead of emoji

8536de91.message: 'cp949' codec can't encode character in Korean text with emoji
8536de91.normalized_pattern: <value> codec can't encode character in Korean text with emoji
contexts: Windows console output with mixed Korean and emoji
8536de91.solution: 1) Use UTF-8 encoding: open(file, encoding='utf-8') 2) Remove emoji 3) Set PYTHONIOENCODING=utf-8

34b5f40a.message: Git diff shows garbled Korean characters
34b5f40a.normalized_pattern: Git diff shows garbled Korean characters
contexts: Git operations on Windows with Korean filenames/content
34b5f40a.solution: git config --global core.quotepath false && git config --global i18n.commitencoding utf-8

c164bcc3.message: Korean characters not saved correctly to file
c164bcc3.normalized_pattern: Korean characters not saved correctly to file
contexts: File.write() without explicit encoding on Windows
c164bcc3.solution: Always use encoding="utf-8": with open(file, "w", encoding="utf-8")

0b2e2e0a.message: Bash heredoc fails with Korean characters on Windows
0b2e2e0a.normalized_pattern: Bash heredoc fails with Korean characters on Windows
contexts: Using cat << 'EOF' with Korean text in git bash
0b2e2e0a.solution: Use Python Write tool instead of bash heredoc for Korean content. Or write to temp file with UTF-8 encoding first
